Gas-phase selective oxidation of toluene with air is a promising method for producing high-purity benzaldehyde, but the yields of existing catalysts are limited, so the development of more efficient catalysts is of great importance to the chemical industry. Herein VMoNb/CeO2 was prepared and characterized by SEM, XRD, Raman, XPS, H2-TPR, and NH3-TPD. The introduction of Mo generated V–O–Mo “asymmetric lattice oxygen” and thus brought high activity. Nb moderated the acidity and oxygen vacancy so as to improve the selectivity. The VMoNb/CeO2 catalyst showed very high catalytic activity at 500 °C, with 35% toluene conversion and 82% benzaldehyde selectivity at an air flow rate of 30 mL/min for V:Mo:Nb =2:5:0.8. This work could serve as a reference for designing mixed metal oxide catalysts for selective oxidation of aromatic hydrocarbons. Graphical abstract VMoNb/CeO2 was developed for the gas phase oxidation of toluene with 35% toluene conversion and 82% benzaldehyde selectivity. The asymmetric lattice oxygen in V-O-Mo contributes to the high activity. While the introduction of Nb could adjust the acidity from strong to medium, thus avoid over oxidation and improve the benzaldehyde selectivity. Image, graphical abstract Keywords V-based catalyst Toluene aerobic oxidation Gas phase Selective oxidation Benzaldehyde Acidity adjustment Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The introduction of oxygen-containing groups into aromatic hydrocarbons by selective oxidation could convert low-cost raw materials to high-value chemical products [1]. However, due to its inertness, high bond dissociation energy (400 kcal mol−1), and weak adsorption on the catalyst surface, C(sp3)-H bond breakage often requires harsh reaction conditions such as high temperature and high pressure, as well as expensive noble-metal-based catalysts, which generates a large amount of toxic waste and results in the over-oxidization of the desired products [2,3]. The selective oxidation of toluene, as one of the representative reactants, to benzyl alcohol, benzaldehyde, and benzoic acid is of great research significance [4-20]. Among them, benzaldehyde has the highest added value and is one of the important organic chemical raw materials and bulk chemicals, which can be used in the production of preservatives, coating resins, dyestuffs, inks, pharmaceuticals, pesticides, plasticizers, and other necessities of life [21-24]. However, due to the halogen residues in the benzaldehyde produced by the main industrial production methods through liquid phase oxidation, it cannot meet the requirements of food, medicine, cosmetics and other fields [25-29]. So it is quite urgent to develop efficient catalysts to prepare chloride-free benzaldehyde through gas phase oxidation. Mehrabi-Kalajahi et al. obtained 18.4% conversion and 84.2% selectivity to benzaldehyde with multi-layered V4AlC3 MAX phase catalyst [30]. Nonetheless, the reaction efficiency is still a long way from industrial production of benzaldehyde by gas phase oxidation, which requires the development of highly efficient catalysts [31]. Among the previous catalytic systems, V-based metal oxides are considered to be the most representative catalytic systems, which are widely used in a variety of hydrocarbon-selective oxidation reactions with excellent performance [32-35]. Usually, V is considered to be the host metal for C-H activation and dominates the catalytic activity of V-containing mixed metal oxides. Nb2O5 has been reported to have abundant acidic sites that greatly facilitate the adsorption-activation process in the reaction [36]. The addition of a small amount of Nb to the catalyst can significantly improve its activity, selectivity, and lifetime of the catalyst. Ali et al. synthesized Cu-Nb dioxide catalysts and found that the introduction of Nb increased the acid amount and NO adsorption capacity [37]. CeO2 has a wide range of applications in the field of catalysis due to the redox cycle between Ce3+ and Ce4+ and its excellent oxygen storage capacity [38-41]. We have developed a V-Ag-Ce/TiO2 catalyst for selective gas-phase oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde [42]. The selectivity reached 92% at conversion of 27% which is the best among the V-based catalyst. However, the cost of the catalyst is high due to the existence of noble metal [43]. The use of non-noble metals to replace precious metals to reduce catalyst costs has always been the goal of the industry [44]. Since the main role of Ag is to reduce the acidity of the catalyst and improve the selectivity of benzaldehyde, it is possible to substitute Nb for Ag. Moreover, we also found that Mo–O–V as “asymmetric lattice oxygen” could bring high activity [45]. Therefore, the introduction of Mo and Nb is promising to replace Ag to obtain the catalyst with both high activity and selectivity. Inspired by previous studies, we herein explored the Mo and Nb doping in V catalyst for the selective oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde. V-Mo-Nb/CeO2 was prepared by the evaporation impregnation method. The effects of Mo and Nb were investigated basing on the catalyst structure, composition, oxygen species, and surface acidity using XRD, XPS, H2-TPR, and NH3-TPD characterizations. In addition, the reaction mechanism and active sites were speculated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and C2H5OH were analytically pure and purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. NH4VO3, C10H5NbO20·xH2O, C2H2O4, CeO2, C6H5C2H5, C6H5CHO, C6H5COOH, and C6H5CH3 were analytically pure and purchased from Aladdin Biochemical Science and Technology Company Limited; O2 (20%)/N2 (80%) were purchased from Panjin Tongyu Gas Co. Deionized water was used for all experiments. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 0.58 g of NH4VO3 (5 mmol) and 2.21 g of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (1.78 mmol) were dissolved in 60 mL of deionized water to form an orange VMo solution after stirring at 80 °C for 30 min. 1.07 g of C10H5NbO20·xH2O (2 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of deionized water and heated by stirring at 60 °C to get the Nb solution. Subsequently, the Nb solution was dropped into the VMo solution, and then 1.5 g of C2H2O4 (16.6 mmol) was added slowly. The solution gradually turned to blue-black, and after stirring for 1 hour, the solution gradually showed a slurry state. Then 1 g of CeO2 (5.8 mmol) was added and stirred for 3 h. After a sufficient reaction, the solvent was completely evaporated at 95 °C, and the resulting product was dried at 110 °C overnight. Finally, the synthesized sample was calcined in air at 600 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 2 °C/min to produce VMoNb/CeO2 catalyst. In the absence of CeO2 or C10H5NbO20·xH2O, VMoNb or VMo/CeO2 catalysts can be obtained according to the above steps. V, Mo, and VMo were also prepared through the same procedure as control catalysts with corresponding precursors. 2.3 Characterization FEI Nova Nano 450 SEM was used to observe the morphology. XRD was performed on Shimadzu Lab 7000 s X-ray diffractometer, with Cu-Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å as the X-ray source and a scanning range of 10–50°. The specific surface area and average pore size were obtained on JWGB BK100C analyzer through N2 adsorption-desorption test. The chemical state of the surface elements was studied by XPS on ESCALAB 250 X-ray spectrometer of Thermo Fisher. Raman spectroscopy was performed via Renishaw inVia instrument. A Micromeritics Auto Chem II 2920 chemisorbent instrument was used to characterize the redox properties and acidity by H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). 2.4 Catalytic oxidation activity test The evaluation of catalyst activity was carried out in a fixed-bed reactor. 1 g of catalyst (20–40 mesh) was loaded into a quartz tube reactor of 55 cm length and 8 mm inner diameter, and the catalyst was purged under an atmosphere of O2/N2 (20 vol% O2/80 vol% N2) for 1 h to eliminate adsorbed substances before the start of the experiment, and then 0.2 mL/min of toluene was passed through the reactor by means of a double-column constant-flow pump. Catalyst activity was evaluated by ramping from room temperature to 500 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. When the reaction stabilized for 0.5 h, the circulation line was condensed by a cryogenic cooling circulation pump with glycol of -30 °C as the cooling liquid medium. The resulting liquid phase products were collected with anhydrous ethanol as solvent and analyzed by a Techcomp GC7900 gas chromatograph. The column used was a capillary column, and the detector was a FID hydrogen flame ion detector. Toluene conversion ( η ), benzaldehyde selectivity ( S ), and benzaldehyde yield ( Y ) were calculated by the following equations: (1) η ( % ) = C 0 − C t C 0 × 100 % (2) S ( % ) = C b C 0 − C t × 100 % (3) Y ( % ) = η × S × 100 % Where C 0 denotes the concentration of toluene before the reaction, C t denotes the concentration of toluene after the reaction, and C b denotes the concentration of benzaldehyde after the reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Surface morphology and element distribution SEM and element mapping was used to explore the morphological characteristics and elemental distribution of the catalysts (Fig. 1 ). As can be seen, the VMo catalyst has a regular plate-like appearance. The VMoNb appeared as square rods in a superposition state with a coarse surface. As for VMoNb/CeO2, array structures that resembled rods and plates can be observed. The appropriate amount of superposition doping of each metal clearly changes the catalyst morphology, exposing more metal active sites on the outer surface and improving the catalyst performance. EDS elemental mapping revealed uniformly dispersed V, Mo, Nb, and Ce elements in VMoNb/CeO2. 3.2 Physical properties Fig. 2 and Table 1 show the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and corresponding pore size distributions. The order of specific surface area of the catalysts was VMo (18.1 m2/g) > VMoNb (16.7 m2/g) > VMoNb/CeO2 (15.5 m2/g) > V (10.5 m2/g) > Mo (6.3 m2/g). Although VMoNb/CeO2 has the smallest specific surface area, it has the best performance. This suggests that S BET may not be the most important factor affecting the activity of mixed metal oxides. As shown in Fig. 2, all catalysts showed type III adsorption isotherms. Considering the low surface area and pore volume, it seems that the catalysts are more likely non-porous materials. The calculated mesopores should stem from the interparticle voids, i.e., piled pores. 3.3 XRD and Raman analysis Fig. 3a shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts. The XRD patterns of V and Mo correspond well with V2O5 (JCPDS# 77–2418) and MoO3 (JCPDS# 76–1003), respectively. When Mo was introduced into V, monoclinic V2MoO8 main crystalline phase was formed (JCPDS #74–1510), indicating the formation of V-O-Mo. The existence of V-O-Mo can be further confirmed by the signal at 938 cm−1 in the Raman spectra shown in Fig. 3b, which is corresponding to the V-O-Mo stretching vibration [45]. The existence of V-O-Mo would significantly enhance the catalytic activity due to the formation of “asymmetric lattice oxygen” (vide infra) [46]. 3.4 XPS analysis In order to understand the surface elements and chemical valence states of the catalysts, XPS analysis was performed, and the results are shown in Fig. 4 and Table 2 . As shown in Fig. 4a, The V 2p3/2 spectra in all catalysts could be deconvoluted to two peaks, which can be attributed to V5+ (517.3 eV) and V4+ (516.2 eV), respectively [45]. Fig. 4b shows the O 1 s spectrum of the samples, where the three fitted peaks of Olatt, Oads, and OOH representing lattice oxygen, surface adsorbed oxygen (representing oxygen vacancy) [47,48], and hydroxyl oxygen, respectively can be obtained [42]. In Mars-van Krevelen mechanism for the catalytic oxidation of toluene, both Oads and Olatt participate in the oxidation reaction. Olatt is the adsorption and oxidation site of toluene, whereas Oads is more favorable for toluene oxidation because it has a higher mobility than Olatt and plays a key role in the replenishment of Olatt [49,50]. The Oads/(Oads+Olatt+OOH) molar ratios in decreasing order were VMo/CeO2 (42%), VMoNb/CeO2 (35%), VMo (31%), and VMoNb (29%). The Ce 3d curve in Fig. 4c is fitted to four pairs of spin-orbit bimodal peaks, among which the peaks denoted as v0, v″, v‴, u0, u″, and u‴ correspond to Ce4+ (3d104f0), and the other peaks correspond to Ce3+ (3d104f1) [51]. The reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ could generate oxygen vacancies. Thus CeO2 drives electron transfer and generates more oxygen vacancies, which improves the mobility and oxygen storage capacity of reactive oxygen species and enhances the toluene conversion. The two peaks around 206.5 and 209.3 eV in Nb 3d in VMoNb and VMoNb/CeO2 (Fig. 4d) indicates that Nb exists in the form of Nb5+. From V 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. 4a), it is obvious that the introduction of Ce significantly increase the content of V4+, while Nb has the opposite effect. From Ce 3d XPS spectrum (Fig. 4c), the introduction of Nb also decrease the ratio of Ce3+. It is well known that the presence of V4+ and Ce3+ usually induces the formation of oxygen vacancies to satisfy the charge balance [51]. Thus the introduction of Nb would suppress the formation of oxygen vacancies. The decrease of oxygen vacancies after the introduction of Nb can also be directly proved according to the O1s XPS spectrum (Fig. 4b). The VMoNb/CeO2 catalyst with the best catalytic performance had a moderate amount of oxygen vacancy, which agrees well with our previous results, where medium amounts of oxygen vacancy were found to be conducive to the conversion of toluene to benzaldehyde [42]. 3.5 H2-TPR and NH3-TPD analysis The redox properties of the catalysts were examined by H2-TPR, and the results are shown in Fig. 5a . The VMo catalyst corresponds to the reduction peak of MoO3 at around 646 °C, followed by a broad peak at around 760 °C, which is a combination of multiple V reduction peaks in V2MoO8. The broad peak corresponds to the reduction of V2O5 to V6O13, followed by further reduction to V2O4. The reduction temperature of VMo/CeO2 is lowered in general, indicating that Ce made it easier for V and Mo to interact with each other. The starting temperatures of VMo and VMoNb catalysts were similar, suggesting that Nb doping has less effect on oxygen mobility. The acidity of the catalyst has been proven to be of great significance to control the selectivity [42]. Using NH3-TPD, the acidity of the catalysts was examined, and the results are shown in Fig. 5b. It can be seen that all catalysts roughly showed two desorption peaks: 200–300 °C and 600–700 °C, which can be attributed to medium acid and strong acid, respectively. VMo and VMo/CeO2 exhibited similar desorption profiles, suggesting that CeO2 has little effect on acidity. However, after the introduction of Nb, the desorption peak of the medium acid sites grew while the peak of the strong acid decreased. Thus the introduction of Nb elevated the amount of medium acid, which favors the adsorption of toluene and enhances its conversion. Meanwhile the introduction of Nb reduced the amount of strong acid, which favors the adsorption of benzaldehyde and enhances its selectivity. The catalytic reaction results show that VMoNb/CeO2 has appropriate acidity for the production of benzaldehyde (vide infra). 3.6 Catalytic performance of toluene oxidation Fig. 6a shows the effect of V/Mo molar ratio on the catalytic performance. As can be seen, the performance of mono-metal V or Mo is poor. After the combination of V and Mo, the catalytic activity is greatly enhanced, which can be attributed to the formation of the “asymmetric lattice oxygen”, i.e., V–O–Mo, which has been proved by XRD and Raman spectrum. It has recently been realized that an asymmetric coordination of cations could make the in-between oxygen “easy come, easy go,” i.e., more active in redox reactions [46,52]. Under the condition of V/Mo = 2:5, the highest benzaldehyde selectivity and yield is obtained. Fig. 6b shows the effect of Nb/V molar ratio on the catalytic performance. With the increase of the ratio of Nb/V, the conversion rate of toluene and the selectivity of benzaldehyde showed a volcanic relationship, and the maximum peak is at Nb/V = 0.4. Thus the optimum catalyst composition is V:Mo:Nb =2:5:0.8. The performance comparison of VMo, VMoNb, VMo/CeO2, and VMoNb/CeO2 was shown in Fig. S1. As can be seen, the introduction of Ce into VMo greatly improved the catalyst activity due to its ability to generate more oxygen vacancies and enhance the mobility of the lattice oxygen. However, the main product over VMo/CeO2 is the undesirable CO2 because of excessive oxidation. Only when Nb was introduced did the product become mainly benzaldehyde. As we know, both toluene and benzaldehyde tend to bind to the acidic sites on the catalyst surface due to their alkalinity [42]. The alkalinity of benzaldehyde is weaker than toluene. So the catalyst with suitable acidity could release the generated benzaldehyde, avoid the over oxidation to benzoic acid or CO2, which makes the oxidation reaction more selective for benzaldehyde. However, if the acidity of the catalyst is too strong, benzaldehyde will not be able to detach from the active sites and over oxidation will happen. As discussed before, the introduction of Nb reduced the amount of strong acid while elevated the amount of medium acid (Fig. 5b). Therefore, Nb mainly plays a role in acid regulation which is crucial to the improvement of benzaldehyde selectivity. The reaction temperature was explored over VMoNb/CeO2, as shown in Fig. 6c. Toluene conversion continued to increase with temperature, while benzaldehyde selectivity gradually increased first and then decreased. High temperature is favorable for the rapid oxidation of toluene and intermediates accumulated on the catalyst surface, leading to a large amount of CO2 production. The appropriate reaction temperature could reduce the occurrence of competing side reactions, such as C-C bond breaking or deep oxidation, in the thermodynamic mechanism, which was conducive to the control of intermediate oxidized product formation. The optimum temperature is 500 °C. Air flow rates in the range of 10–150 mL/min were explored over VMoNb/CeO2 and the results are shown in Fig. 6d. When the air flow rate is 10 mL/min, the conversion of toluene is low due to that oxygen is not enough to re-oxidize the catalyst completely at the low O2/C7H8 molar ratio. Therefore, during the catalyst regeneration step, the amount of oxygen entering the catalyst was insufficient to generate sufficient lattice oxygen. Consequently, the catalyst did not regenerate completely, which hindered the reaction and resulted in a decrease in toluene conversion. When the air flow rate is 30 mL/min, 35% conversion of toluene and 82% selectivity of benzaldehyde are obtained, and when the air flow rate is 60 mL/min, 60% conversion of toluene and 58% selectivity of benzaldehyde are obtained. When air flow goes up, toluene conversion goes up a lot, but the benzaldehyde selectivity goes down significantly. This is because an excess of oxygen will cause further oxidation of the benzaldehyde to benzoic acid or CO2. Though the yield at 30 mL/min is lower than that of 60 mL/min, the benzaldehyde selectivity is much higher. Since it is more economical to recycle toluene than convert it to undesirable side products, 30 mL/min is considered to be the more favorable condition. According to the data in the Table S1, among the reported V-based catalysts for toluene gas-phase oxidation, the VMoNb/CeO2 gives the highest yield under optimal conditions. The VMoNb/CeO2 catalyst also had good stability, as shown in Fig. S2, and maintained a high reaction efficiency during the 20-hour reaction period. 3.7 Reaction mechanism hypothesis The hypothetical reaction mechanism of toluene oxidation to benzaldehyde over VMoNb/CeO2 was proposed in Fig. 7 . Firstly, the weakly basic toluene is adsorbed on the acidic sites of the catalyst surface. Then a hydrogen atom of the side chain methyl group is taken away by V=O to form an active intermediate. Subsequently, the active asymmetric lattice oxygen in the V-O-Mo as a nucleophile attacks the methyl carbon, meanwhile another hydrogen atom is taken away by Mo=O. A new aldehyde group is thus formed with the break of a C-H bond. With the departure of the lattice oxygen, oxygen vacancy is formed on the catalyst surface. The less alkaline benzaldehyde is then desorbed from the medium acidic catalyst surface, preventing further over oxidation to produce benzoic acid and carbon oxides. The gas-phase oxygen replenishes the oxygen vacancy and H2O is desorbed through the dehydroxylation reaction, allowing the catalyst to recover and complete a catalytic cycle. It can be seen from the hypothetical mechanism that the active lattice oxygen helps enhance the activity, while the medium acidity guarantees the selectivity. 4 Conclusion In this paper, a VMoNb/CeO2 mixed metal oxide was designed and prepared as an efficient catalyst for the gas-phase selective oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde. The catalytic performance of V was modulated by Mo and Nb doping, and the results demonstrated that VMoNb/CeO2 had higher catalytic activity, benzaldehyde selectivity, and long-lasting stability. The introduction of Mo can form V-O-Mo "asymmetric lattice oxygen", which is much more active than the pristine lattice oxygen and conducive to selective oxidation. The doping of Nb could suppress the formation of oxygen vacancies and adjust the acidity from strong to medium, so as to avoid over oxidation and improve the benzaldehyde selectivity. The results of this study could provide a reference for the design of an efficient catalytic system for the selective oxidation of aromatic hydrocarbons. coredata.dc:description: Gas-phase selective oxidation of toluene with air is a promising method for producing high-purity benzaldehyde, but the yields of existing catalysts are limited, so the development of more efficient catalysts is of great importance to the chemical industry. Herein VMoNb/CeO2 was prepared and characterized by SEM, XRD, Raman, XPS, H2-TPR, and NH3-TPD. The introduction of Mo generated V–O–Mo “asymmetric lattice oxygen” and thus brought high activity. Nb moderated the acidity and oxygen vacancy so as to improve the selectivity. The VMoNb/CeO2 catalyst showed very high catalytic activity at 500 °C, with 35% toluene conversion and 82% benzaldehyde selectivity at an air flow rate of 30 mL/min for V:Mo:Nb =2:5:0.8. This work could serve as a reference for designing mixed metal oxide catalysts for selective oxidation of aromatic hydrocarbons.
